course.subject: BIBU
course.name: Biotechnology Management
course.description: This course provides students with a general outlook of the roles and responsibilities in managing the biotech business. Business constraints like sales and marketing, partnerships, critical success factors in operations, market entry barriers, risk management and relationships with stakeholders will be covered in this course, with special focus on strategic development in the biotech business. Guest speakers will contribute their personal experience to offer a professional view of the key issues, pitfalls and opportunities in their daily business activity. A large use of case studies and other process management techniques will simulate potential scenarios in which students may be called to operate soon after they completed their university career. For BIBU students in their fourth year of study only.

reviews.author: anony262
reviews.title: Word of advice: Lube Up
reviews.comment_content:
In all honesty, the course content can be very helpful depending on what you want to do in the biotech field. However, what's NOT fun is having to memorise certain shipping procedures and lame-ass leadership theories (tf is Belbin's typology?). Furthermore, the majority of the "good" content will NOT be tested on and you'll be stuck wondering how to correctly order a resource-based strategy. Basically, it's a load of bollocks.

Course Content:
1. FIPCO
2. Strategy I
3. Strategy II
4. Business Development
5. Business Plan I
6. Business Plan II
7. Regulatory Compliance I
8. Regulatory Compliance II
9. Project Management
10. Corporate and Product Risk I
11. Corporate and Product Risk II
12. Partnerships
13. Valuation I
14. Valuation II
15. Board Room
16. Leadership (lol)

To sum it up, a lot of content that, delivered the right way, could be interesting. However, you'll either be experiencing information overload or sheer boredom.
reviews.comment_teaching: The guy is nice, however the emotional destruction you'll feel from the exam will completely obliterate that feeling. Classes are generally hard to pay attention in as engagement is not really there. The dry delivery as well makes it so that you'll find yourself drifting off to social media to find something new and fascinating.
reviews.comment_grading:
Granted, finals grades have not come out, but if they're anything like the rest of HKUST, it'll be a real pain in the rear.

Midterm: Mean was 47/60, got slightly above mean

When studying, try to identify all the things that seem important. Then, completely throw that out the window and memorize only the most random information. Do that, and you'll be on your way to A-range.
reviews.comment_workload:
1000+ slides is a bit overkill, especially when those slides have an enormous amount of detail you have to remember. Don't bother actually trying to understand the content, just memorize the little details that you'll no doubt forget the following day.

The project is also quite a mess. 13 people per group is a great way to find yourself in a situation with a lot of free riders. Enjoy leading that project all on your own!

Basically, unless you're a BIBU student, avoid this course like you'd avoid someone without a mask.

reviews.author: 1emon
reviews.title: A FUCKING NIGHTMARE
reviews.comment_content: Nothing special; covers any topic related to pharma industry. Contents are unorganized and contain "too much" information (in total 1,000+a slides). Random tables/graphs/charts everywhere in between slides. I wonder why this course became a compulsory course for BIBU major.
reviews.comment_teaching: Basically reading off his miserable ppts with typos in his broken, Italian english. It is extremely difficult to follow his teaching during the lecture. Seems like no one is actually paying attention to the class.
reviews.comment_grading:
50% Final Exam (Online, "Closed book in principle" srsly??)
30% Group project (No clear instruction; all he said was to write something that makes sense lol)
10% Peer Evaluation (F**k free-riders)
10% Attendance (You better put your camera on)
reviews.comment_workload: No assignments but a group project (around 12-3 members per team) and an individual exam (covering 1,000+a slides).

- FIPCO

- Business Development

reviews.author: torterral_Tsui
reviews.title: The most intensive f*cking shit.
reviews.comment_content:
Very comprehensive and intensive.
Essentially it is ECON2103 + ECON2123 + FINA2203 + ISOM2700 + MARK2120 + MGMT2110 + LIFS4200 in 1 semester.

Rewarding and useful, but assessments and grading are shit.

Overall >1000 slides for 1 final exam that worth 50% of the grade, every single slide is full of contents and explanations. Good luck.

You need to prepare a full business pitch of 40 slides using EXACTLY THE SAME framework Prof taught in class throughout the semester. The whole 12-13 people team will be divided into Business Development, Marketing, Sales and Finance teams.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Although the amount of contents is inhumane, the teaching is actually okay. He speaks and explains clearly.

Falling asleep in the class is easy. After 5 minutes you wake up and you can still catch the contents. That being said, the next day you will forget almost everything Prof said in class.

Prof will be answering your questions on the project, but he will give no advice. It is all YOUR choice and YOU are responsible for every decision you make. Treat Prof as your boss in the workplace.

As Prof always stresses in class. The project (and the class) is just to give you pain. The whole thing is to let you experience the actual world and how your colleagues will be playing games over the table. It is nothing scientific. None of the contents will make you an expert of the field.
reviews.comment_grading:
Poor grading. Got destroyed.

Exam 50%
Project 30%
Attendance 10%
Peer evaluation 10%

Step mean on exam, got B.
reviews.comment_workload:
Stressful throughout.

Exam is of all MC format, closed-book. Syllabus > 1000 slides.

Project is the most stressful one in UST, and highly depends on your groupmates. I have some good groupmates luckily. Communication is of utmost importance in this project and believe me, it is very difficult.
